It is practically the only comprehensive book on queen rearing
A guide to the beekeeping industry of Ireland

author.given: British Beekeeper's Guide Book By T.W.

note: ; First Lessons in Beekeeping. By C. P. Dadant. A new revision of the old book by Thos. Newman. 200 pages price, 50c. ;
title: This is the leading work on practical beekeeping in England
A work on the natural history,anatomy and physiology of bees
An extensive treatise on beeswax
The Lore op the Honey Bee. By Tiekner Edwards. An interesting book of information about bees in general

note: figs. A general account of the management of bees.
title: A number of valuable bulletins on various subjects of interest to beekeepers, are published by the Department of Agriculture. They are prepared in the Bureau of Entomology and arc for free distribution. The following may be obtained by addressing the Secretary of Agriculture
The Treatment of Bee Diseases
This publication gives briefly the symptoms of the various bee diseases, with directions for treatment
The Cause of American Foul Brood
This publication contains a brief account of the investigations which demonstrated for the first time the cause of one of the brood diseases of bees, American foul brood

note: A record of the localities from which samples of diseased brood were received prior to
title: The Occurrence of Bee Diseases in the United States

author.family: Queen Bees." By E. F. Phillips

title: A general account of the methods used in queen rearing. Several methods are given, so that the beekeeper may choose those best suited to his individual needs
Report of the Meeting of Inspectors of Apiaries

Contains a brief history of bee-disease investigations, an account of the relationship of bacteria to bee diseases, and a discussion of treatment by various inspectors of apiaries and other practical beekeepers who are familiar with diseases of bees

author.literal: Part I, "Production and Care of Extracted Honey." By E. F. Phillips, Ph. D.

note: The second portion of the publication gives some simple tests for adulteration.
title: Methods of Honev Testing for Beekeepers
The methods of producing extracted honey, with special reference to the care of honey after it is taken from the bees, so that its value may not be decreased by improper handling

author.literal: Part II, "Wax Moths and American Foul Brood." By E. F. Phillips, Ph. D.

title: An account of the behavior of the two species of wax moths on combs containing American foul brood, showing that moths do not destroy the disease-carrying scales

author.literal: Part III, "Bee Disease in Massachusetts." By Burton N. Gates.

title: An account of the distribution of the brood diseases of bees in the State, with brief directions for controlling them
The Relation of the Etiology (cause) of Bee Diseases to the Treatment
The necessity for a knowledge of the cause of bee diseases before rational treatment is possible is pointed out. The present state of knowledge of the causes of disease is summarized

author.literal: Part V, "A Brief Survey of Hawaiian Beekeeping." By E. F. Phillips, Ph. D.

title: 6 plates. An account of the beekeeping methods used in a tropical country and a comparison with mainland conditions
The Status of Apiculture in the United States
A survey of present-day beekeeping in the United States, with suggestions as to the work yet to be done before apiculture will have reached its fullest development

author.literal: Part VII, "Beekeeping in Massachusetts." By Burton N. Gates.

title: An account of a detailed study of the apicultural conditions in Massachusetts. The object of this paper is to point out the actual conditions and needs of beekeeping in New England
75, Contents and Index
75, Parts I- VII, complete with Contents and Index
Historical Notes on the Causes of Bee Diseases
A summary of the various investigations concerning the etiology (cause) of bee diseases

note: Astudy of the bacteria present in both the healthy and the diseased colony, with special reference to the diseases of bees.
title: The Bacteria of the Apiary, with Special Reference to Bee Diseases
The Anatomy of the Honey Bee

An account of the structure of the bee, with technical terms omitted so far as possible. Practically all of the illustrations are new, and the various parts are interpreted according to the best usage in comparative anatomy of insects. A brief discussion of the physiology of the various organs is included

author.nick: A Microscopical Study of Honey PoUen.

note: By means of this work the detection of honey adulteration is much aided.
title: Chemical Analysis and Composition of American Honeys

A comprehensive study of the chemical composition of American honeys. This publication is technical in nature and will perhaps be little used by practical beekeepers, but it is an important contribution to apicultural literature
